metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: XML DOM Nodes
According to the XML DOM, everything in an XML document is a node :
content.html: According to the XML DOM, everything in an XML document is a node:

content.text: DOM Example
Look at the following XML file ( books.xml ):
content.html: Look at the following XML file (books.xml):

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<bookstore>


<book category="cooking">


<title lang="en">Everyday Italian</title>


<author>Giada De Laurentiis</author>


<year>2005</year>


<price>30.00</price>


</book>


<book category="children">


<title lang="en">Harry Potter</title>


<author>J K. Rowling</author>


<year>2005</year>


<price>29.99</price>


</book>


<book category="web">


<title lang="en">XQuery Kick Start</title>


<author>James McGovern</author>


<author>Per Bothner</author>


<author>Kurt Cagle</author>


<author>James Linn</author>


<author>Vaidyanathan Nagarajan</author>


<year>2003</year>


<price>49.99</price>


</book>


<book category="web" cover="paperback">


<title lang="en">Learning XML</title>


<author>Erik T. Ray</author>


<year>2003</year>


<price>39.95</price>


</book>

</bookstore>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<bookstore>
  <book category="cooking">
    <title lang="en">Everyday Italian</title>
    <author>Giada De Laurentiis</author>
    <year>2005</year>
    <price>30.00</price>
  </book>
  <book category="children">
    <title lang="en">Harry Potter</title>
    <author>J K. Rowling</author>
    <year>2005</year>
    <price>29.99</price>
  </book>
  <book category="web">
    <title lang="en">XQuery Kick Start</title>
    <author>James McGovern</author>
    <author>Per Bothner</author>
    <author>Kurt Cagle</author>
    <author>James Linn</author>
    <author>Vaidyanathan Nagarajan</author>
    <year>2003</year>
    <price>49.99</price>
  </book>
  <book category="web" cover="paperback">
    <title lang="en">Learning XML</title>
    <author>Erik T. Ray</author>
    <year>2003</year>
    <price>39.95</price>
  </book>
</bookstore>

content.text: The root node in the XML above is named <bookstore>.
content.html: The root node in the XML above is named <bookstore>.

content.text: All other nodes in the document are contained within <bookstore>.
content.html: All other nodes in the document are contained within <bookstore>.

content.text: The root node <bookstore> holds 4 <book> nodes.
content.html: The root node <bookstore> holds 4 <book> nodes.

content.text: The first <book> node holds the child nodes: <title>, <author>, <year>, and <price>.
content.html: The first <book> node holds the child nodes: <title>, <author>, <year>, and <price>.

content.text: The child nodes contain one text node each, "Everyday Italian", "Giada De Laurentiis", "2005", and "30.00".
content.html: The child nodes contain one text node each, "Everyday Italian", "Giada De Laurentiis", "2005", and "30.00".

content.text: Text is Always Stored in Text Nodes
A common error in DOM processing is to expect an element node to contain text.
content.html: A common error in DOM processing is to expect an element node to contain text.

content.text: However, the text of an element node is stored in a text node.
content.html: However, the text of an element node is stored in a text node.

content.text: In this example: <year>2005</year> , the element node <year> holds a text node with the value "2005".
content.html: In this example: <year>2005</year>, the element node <year> holds a text node with the value "2005".

content.text: "2005" is not the value of the <year> element!
content.html: "2005" is not the value of the <year> element!

content.text: The XML DOM Node Tree
The XML DOM views an XML document as a tree-structure. The tree structure is called a node-tree.
content.html: The XML DOM views an XML document as a tree-structure. The tree structure is called a node-tree.

content.text: All nodes can be accessed through the tree. Their contents can be modified or deleted, and new elements can be created.
content.html: All nodes can be accessed through the tree. Their contents can be modified or deleted, and new elements can be created.

content.text: The node tree shows the set of nodes, and the connections between them. The tree starts at the root node and branches out to the text nodes at the lowest level of the tree:
content.html: The node tree shows the set of nodes, and the connections between them. The tree starts at the root node and branches out to the text nodes at the lowest level of the tree:

content.text: The image above represents the XML file books.xml .
content.html: The image above represents the XML file books.xml.

content.text: Node Parents, Children, and Siblings
The nodes in the node tree have a hierarchical relationship to each other.
content.html: The nodes in the node tree have a hierarchical relationship to each other.

content.text: The terms parent, child, and sibling are used to describe the relationships. Parent nodes have children. Children on the same level are called siblings (brothers or sisters).
content.html: The terms parent, child, and sibling are used to describe the relationships. Parent nodes have children. Children on the same level are called siblings (brothers or sisters).

content.text: The following image illustrates a part of the node tree and the relationship between the nodes:
content.html: The following image illustrates a part of the node tree and the relationship between the nodes:

content.text: Because the XML data is structured in a tree form, it can be traversed without knowing the exact structure of the tree and without knowing the type of data contained within.
content.html: Because the XML data is structured in a tree form, it can be traversed without knowing the exact structure of the tree and without knowing the type of data contained within.

content.text: You will learn more about traversing the node tree in a later chapter of this tutorial.
content.html: You will learn more about traversing the node tree in a later chapter of this tutorial.

content.text: First Child - Last Child
Look at the following XML fragment:
content.html: Look at the following XML fragment:

content.code_html:
<bookstore>
  <book category="cooking">
    <title lang="en">Everyday Italian</title>
    <author>Giada De Laurentiis</author>
    <year>2005</year>
    <price>30.00</price>
  </book>
</bookstore>

content.text: In the XML above, the <title> element is the first child of the <book> element, and the <price> element is the last child of the <book> element.
content.html: In the XML above, the <title> element is the first child of the <book> element, and the <price> element is the last child of the <book> element.

content.text: Furthermore, the <book> element is the parent node of the <title>, <author>, <year>, and <price> elements.
content.html: Furthermore, the <book> element is the parent node of the <title>, <author>, <year>, and <price> elements.
